headline.main: Stroke Risk: The Rise and Fall

docs.abstract: Dr Tobias Kurth, Brigham and Woman's Hospital neurologist, leads study published in online issue of journal Stroke that finds women who smoke are at greater risk for hemorrhagic strokes; women smoking more than 15 cigarettes daily are more than twice as likely to have such strokes, but risk decreases dramatically and quickly when women stop smoking; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Women who smoke are at much higher risk for bleeding strokes, but those who have quit can bring their risk back to normal, researchers have found. The study found that women who smoked 15 or more cigarettes a day were more than twice as likely to suffer this kind of stroke, described as hemorrhagic, which causes severe injury and often death. And the more they smoke, the higher the risk, according to a report in the current online issue of the journal Stroke.
